issues.description: Resource path naming is inconsistent between the problem statement and the solution server: the problem statement specifies endpoints under /persons (POST /persons, GET /persons, PUT /persons/{personId}, DELETE /persons/{personId}), but the solution's server implementation exposes the endpoints under /people (e.g. @GetMapping("people"), @PostMapping("people")). This is a cross-artifact conflict that will confuse students about which path to implement and test against, and may cause students to implement endpoints at /persons while the reference server uses /people (or vice versa).
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the resource path naming across problem statement, template, and solution. Preferably keep the problem statement and template as the source of truth for students: change the server (solution) endpoints to use /persons for all operations (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) or change the problem statement to consistently use /people. Also update the client controller URIs accordingly so server and client use the same base path.

issues.description: Internal inconsistency inside the solution repository: the solution client (PersonController) uses mixed resource paths — some methods call /people (addPerson, updatePerson) while others call /persons (deletePerson, getAllPersons). At the same time the solution server exposes /people. This mismatch between client and server inside the solution will cause the provided reference client to fail for some operations and is likely to confuse students who inspect the solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make client and server use the same, consistent resource path. Choose one canonical path (either /persons or /people) and update all uses in the solution client and server so that add/update/delete/getAll all use that path. Prefer updating to match the problem statement (/persons) so students following the text and template are not confused, and ensure the template client/controller examples (if present) use the same path as well.

issues.description: Endpoint resource name for the Person entity is inconsistent across artifacts. The problem statement explicitly lists the REST paths as /persons (POST /persons, GET /persons, PUT /persons/{personId}, DELETE /persons/{personId}) but the solution server implements the endpoints under the path "people" (e.g. @GetMapping("people"), @PostMapping("people"), @PutMapping("people/{personId}")). The solution client is also inconsistent: some client methods call the server under "people" (add/update use "people/..."), while others use "persons" (getAll and delete use "persons/..." in the provided client implementation). The template contains the PersonController/PersonResource stubs but no endpoints yet, which leaves students to map the problem description to the template — the differing names between problem and solution (and the mixed usage within the solution client) will create confusion and integration errors. Students following the problem statement and template would expect and implement /persons, but the server in the solution expects /people; additionally the mixed URIs in the solution client will lead to runtime mismatches. This inconsistent naming for the same conceptual entity (persons/people) creates a high cognitive and practical integration burden.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the endpoint resource name for the Person entity across all artifacts. Prefer matching the problem statement to avoid confusing students: change the server mappings from "people" to "persons" (e.g. @GetMapping("persons"), @PostMapping("persons"), @PutMapping("persons/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping("persons/{personId}")), and update the client to consistently use the same path (use "persons" for add/update/delete/get). Alternatively, if "people" is preferred, update the problem statement and all client code to use "people" consistently. Ensure all client methods use the same base path to avoid mixed usages.
